mods.abstract: $100 REWARDI WILL give the above reward for my boy BILL, who ranaway on the 7th April, from my plantation in Walker county, if taken up by any person west of the San Antonio river; fifty dollars if taken up west of the Brazos, and twenty-five dollars if taken up east of the Brazos riverThe above reward will be paid by delivering said boy into the hands of any jailor convenient to where taken up, and where he will be securely kept until I can get himBill is what would be called a bright mulatto, of rather dull expression of countenance, his hair might be called bright and when long, very bushy: was very long when he left homeHis age is about 28 years, his height five feet ten inchesTook with him from home a double-barrel shot gunWMBSCOTTHuntsville, Texas, May, 1855 j6 The Galveston News, South-Western, Shreveport, and Houston Telegraph, will publish four times and send bill to the Presbyterian office.
mods.note: Louisiana State University Libraries, Special Collections ( http://www.lib.lsu.edu/special )
mods.accessCondition: E-mail lsudiglib@lsu.edu with questions or comments about the collection.

Physical rights are retained by the LSU LibrariesCopyright has expired and the item is therefore in the public domainPermission to reproduce this image must be requested through the Special Collections Department, Louisiana State University Libraries.
mods.note: Louisiana Runaway Slave Advertisements, 1836-1865, Louisiana Digital Library, Baton Rouge, La.
